questions.text: The suprascapular nerve is the content of which of the following triangles marked in the neck region?
questions.solution:
The suprascapular nerve (C5, C6) arises from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. The nerve is a component of the subclavian triangle.

In the given image:

  • A – Carotid triangle
  • B – Occipital triangle 
  • C – Subclavian triangle
  • D – Muscular triangle

Contents of the subclavian triangle are:

  • 3rd part of Subclavian Artery and vein
  • Suprascapular artery and vein, transverse cervical artery
  • Supraclavicular lymph node
  • Trunks of Brachial plexus
  • Nerve to Serratus anterior
  • Branches from upper trunk – N to Subclavius, Suprascapular nerve

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of severe pain in her buttocks. The muscle marked in the image below is suspected to be inflamed. Which of the following nerves is likely to be involved due to its inflammation?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is the piriformis and the clinical features are suggestive of piriformis syndrome. This occurs due to the entrapment of the sciatic nerve.

Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle. This can occur due to inflammation of the piriformis muscle. The patient will present with pain along the distribution of the sciatic nerve which is also known as sciatica. It is triggered by sitting for a long time or running, climbing stairs, or applying firm pressure directly over the piriformis muscle.

Early signs include pain, tingling, or numbness in the buttocks. Later it may lead to severe pain extending down the length of the sciatic nerve.

questions.text: The structure marked in the cadaveric image given below, arises at the ______
questions.solution:
The marked structure can be identified as the superior mesenteric artery, as it lies anterior and superior to the left renal vein. The superior mesenteric artery originated from the abdominal aorta at the level of the lower border of the L1 vertebra, about 1 cm below the celiac trunk .

Their branches are:

  • Jejunal branches
  • Ileal branches
  • Middle colic artery
  • Right colic artery
  • Ileocolic artery
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

Clinical note - Nutcracker syndrome:

  • The compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, appears in the sagittal plane, as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (left renal vein).
  • This condition is called nutcracker (left renal vein entrapment) syndrome.

questions.text: Given below is a dissected compartment of the leg. The nerve supplying these muscles does not give articular branches to?
questions.solution:
The given muscle is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve. It does not give articular branches to the 2nd metatarsophalangeal joint. 

The above image shows the anterior compartment of the leg. The deep peroneal nerve is the nerve of the anterior compartment of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. It is one of the two terminal branches of the common peroneal nerve arising between the neck of the fibula and peroneus longus. It accompanies the anterior tibial artery. 

The deep peroneal nerve gives articular branches to-

  • Ankle joint
  • Tarsal joints
  • Tarsometatarsal joints
  • 1st metatarsophalangeal joint

Muscular branches-

  • Tibialis anterior 
  • Extensor hallucis longus 
  • Extensor digitorium  longus
  • Peroneus tertius 
  • Extensor digitorium brevis 

The 2nd metatarsophalangeal joint is supplied by the medial plantar nerve.

 

Related Pearl: Various muscles of the leg and their innervation:

 

Muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg and dorsum of foot

Nerve Supply

Tibialis anterior

 

 

Deep Peroneal Nerve

Extensor hallucis longus

Extensor digitorum longus

Extensor digitorum brevis

questions.text: A cadaveric specimen of the circle of Willis is given below. Which of the following marked structures represents the superior cerebellar artery?
questions.solution:
The given cadaveric image is of the vascular structures(Circle of Willis) at the base of the brain. The structure marked as 'A' can be identified as the superior cerebellar artery as it is arising from the distal portion of the basilar artery, immediately before the formation of the posterior cerebral arteries(marked as B).

The superior cerebellar artery supplies the pons, pineal body, superior medullary velum and tela choroidea of the third ventricle.

Circle of Willis or circulus arteriosus: Large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns that surround the optic chiasma and infundibulum.

The anterior cerebral arteries are derived from the internal carotid arteries and are linked by a small anterior communicating artery.

Posteriorly, the two posterior cerebral arteries are formed by the division of the basilar artery. They are joined to the ipsilateral internal carotid artery by a posterior communicating artery.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve that passes through the marked foramen marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the superior orbital fissure and the oculomotor nerve passes through this fissure.

Superior orbital fissure is divided into three compartments by the common tendinous ring. The oculomotor nerve passes through its intermediate compartment.

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with rigidity, frequent falls, slow movements, tremors, and a short stepping gait when he entered the doctor's room. Which of the following areas is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Parkinson's disease, which is associated with the degeneration of substantia nigra (marked as "C").

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease,  there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Postural instability along with bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are cardinal features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Notable gait abnormalities are:

  • Short stepped gait- parkinsonism
  • Scissoring gait- spasticity i.e. UMN lesion
  • High-stepped, slapping gait- posterior column or peripheral nerve disease
  • Waddling gait- proximal muscle weakness
  • Wide stepping gait - cerebellar dysfunction

questions.text: The middle meningeal artery enters into the middle cranial fossa through which of the following foramina?
questions.solution:
The middle meningeal artery enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen spinosum, labelled as 3 in the image.

Foramina marked in the image are

1 - Foramen rotundum

2 - Foramen ovale

3 - Foramen spinosum

4 - Jugular foramen

The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the first part of maxillary artery, given off in the infratemporal fossa. In here it first runs upwards and medially between the sphenomandibular ligament and lateral pterygoid muscle and then passes through a loop formed by the two roots of the auriculotemporal nerve.
Following this, it enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen spinosum; following which it has an extradural course. It runs forward and laterally, grooving the squamous temporal bone and gives rise to its frontal and parietal branches.

The middle meningeal artery is predominantly a periosteal artery which supplies the bone and red bone marrow in the diploe.

questions.text: Identify the marked artery.
questions.solution:
The artery marked is the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. This artery branches out from the vertebral artery and it is the largest branch of the vertebral artery.

The following image shows the circle of Willis.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the diagram below:
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the Lacunar ligament.

Lacunar (Gimbernats) ligament - It is a thick triangular band of tissue formed from fibres of the medial end of the inguinal ligament and fascia lata.  It forms the medial wall of the femoral canal. The apex of the triangle is attached to the pubic tubercle.

Inguinal (Poupart’s) ligament - The thick external oblique aponeurosis stretched between ASIS (anterior superior iliac spine) and pubic tubercle. 

Pectineal (Astley Coopers) ligament - A strong fibrous band that extends laterally along the pectineal line from the pectineal attachment of Lacunar ligament.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The median nerve supplies the 1st lumbrical which is marked. 

There are four lumbrical muscles. They originate from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus. It passes to the radial side of the corresponding fingers and is inserted into the dorsal digital expansion of the extensor digitorum.

The action of lumbricals is flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joint and extension of interphalangeal joints. 

Lumbricals can be tested only along with interosseous muscle. The examiner will hold the metacarpophalangeal joint of the index finger in hyperextension. Then the patient is asked to extend the proximal interphalangeal joint against resistance. The test is repeated on other fingers as well.

The median nerve innervates the first and second lumbricals. The deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve innervates the third and the fourth. 

The median nerve is formed by the union of the lateral root (C6, 7) from the lateral cord, and the medial root (C8, T1) from the medial cord.

On the hand, it is seen proximal to the flexor retinaculum and lateral to the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis. It also lies between the tendons of flexor carpi radialis and palmaris longus.

Its cutaneous supply in hand is as follows: 

  • Lateral 2/3rd of the palm by superficial cutaneous branch
  • Lateral 3½ fingers (palmar aspect and dorsal aspect of nailbeds) by palmar digital nerves

The muscles supplied by the median nerve in the hand are flexor pollicis brevis, abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, and first dorsal interosseous.

The median nerve sometimes gets compressed under the fibro-osseous tunnel beneath the flexor retinaculum leading to carpal tunnel syndrome. 

Pen test is used to test the median nerve in the hand. It tests the abductor pollicis brevis muscle.  The hand must remain flat with the palm facing upwards. A pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb.

Related Pearl: Upper limb nerve integrity tests

 Nerve

questions.text: Which of the following post-mortem changes is a result of hydrolysis of lipids under warm and humid weather?
questions.solution:
Hydrolysis of lipids under warm and humid weather would result in adipocere formation, which is seen in image 4. 

Postmortem changes are classified on the basis of time:

  • Immediate signs of death (at the time of somatic or clinical death):
    1. Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
    2. Cessation of respiration
    3. Cessation of circulation
  • Early signs of death. It is seen in cellular death:
    1. Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin
    2. Eye changes
    3. Primary flaccidity of muscles
    4. Algor mortis/Postmortem cooling
    5. Postmortem lividity/Suggillation
    6. Rigor mortis
  • Late signs of death:
    1. Putrefaction
    2. Adipocere
    3. Mummification

Adipocere formation (Image 4) is a late sign of death. The transformation is brought about by the gradual hydrolysis and hydrogenation of pre-existing fats, including olein, into higher fatty acids. These higher fatty acids then join with calcium and ammonium ions to produce insoluble soaps, which since they are acidic, prevent putrefactive bacteria. The usual time for adipocere formation is between 3 to 6 months. Still, in countries like India, it is accelerated by the warm and humid weather, resulting in the beginning of adipocere formation as early as 4 to 5 days after death. 

Image 1. Marbling: It is seen when blood in the vessels is hemolyzed to sulfate-hemoglobin, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin begins at about 24 hours and becomes prominent  36–48 hours after death. It is a visible postmortem change that is characterized by linear branching patterns on skin that correspond to the course of superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

Image 2. Cadaveric lividity: Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in most superficial layers of the dermis in the dependent parts of the body. Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6 – 12 hours after death and persists until putrefaction sets in.

Image 3. Mummification: It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry or warmed air. It is a process of dehydration or drying and shriveling of the cadaver that occurs from the evaporation of water. The natural appearances of the body and general facial features are preserved.

questions.text: A lesion of the structure marked in the below image causes?
questions.solution: The structure marked in the image is the pyramid containing the pyramidal tracts. A lesion here leads to contralateral hemiplegia.

questions.text: Identify the muscle marked as A in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The muscle labeled as A is anconeus and its functions are

  • Abduction of the wrist in pronated position
  • Accessory extension of elbow joint

Other options: 

  • The muscle marked as B is extensor carpi radialis brevis, and it extends and abducts the wrist joint
  • The muscle marked as C is extensor digitorum, and it mainly extends the index, middle, ring, and little fingers and also extends the wrist.
  • The muscle marked as D is extensor carpi ulnaris, and it extends and adducts the wrist joint.

questions.text: The diaphragmatic surface of the heart is shown below. Identify the structures marked X and Y.

choices.text: Posterior interventricular artery and middle cardiac vein
Posterior interventricular artery and small cardiac vein
Right coronary artery and middle cardiac vein
Left coronary artery and small cardiac vein

questions.solution:
The structure marked X is the posterior interventricular artery and the structure marked Y is the middle cardiac vein which can be identified as it drains into the coronary sinus. Both these structures lie in the posterior interventricular sulcus.

Tributaries of coronary sinus include the following:

  • Great cardiac vein
  • Middle cardiac vein
  • Small cardiac vein
  • Posterior vein of the left ventricle
  • Oblique vein(of Marshall) of the left atrium 

Related Pearl: Structures passing through heart sulci

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle marked as A in the image below, at the metacarpophalangeal joint?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked 'A' are lumbricals and they cause flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints.

Lumbricals are intrinsic muscles of the hand that flex the metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP) and extend the interphalangeal joints (PIP & DIP).

They originate from Flexor digitorum profundus.

  • The lateral two are unipennate, supplied by the Median nerve.
  • The medial two are bipinnate, supplied by the Ulnar nerve.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the ulnar artery, seen contributing to the superficial palmar arch.

It passes deep to the Guyon's canal in the wrist and contributes to the superficial and deep palmar arch.

questions.text: The following image shows first cervical vertebra, superior view. Part of the bone marked as Number 7 gives attachment to:
questions.solution:
Part of bone (Atlas) marked as number 7 is posterior arch, and its inferior border gives attachment to ligamentum flavum.

Atlas (C1)

Atlanto-occipital joint allowing head nodding up and down (like showing yes).

Atlanto-axial joint allow head turning side to side (like showing no).

Bony features: 

  • No body, No spinous process 
  • 2 lateral masses - with upper and lower articular facets
  • 2 - anterior and posterior arches 
  • 2 transverse process with lateral transverse foramen - through which vertebral vessels pass through

Important Attachments:

  • Anterior arch - anteriorly attached to the "anterior longitudinal ligament", posteriorly articulates with "facet of dens" 
  • Posterior arch - superior border attached to "atlantooccipital membrane", inferior border attached to "ligamentum flavum"

 Axis (C2)

Bony features: 

  • Cylindrical body, transverse process with transverse foramen and bifid spine
  • Dens (odontoid process) project up to space left by "missing" body of C1

Clinical consideration

  • Stability of the vertebral column is maintained mainly by 4 ligaments - Anterior longitudinal, Posterior longitudinal, Ligamentum flavum and Interspinous ligament.
  • C1 compression fracture at multiple sites "Jefferson fracture" and C2 hyperextension fracture "hangman fracture".

Other options:

  • Ligamentum nuchae-the posterior tubercle provides attachment for ligamentum nuchae.

questions.text: A boy with a history of a fall from a tree presents with a lurching gait and dragging of his feet. Which of the following structures are involved?
questions.solution:
The structure responsible for lurching gait in the child is gluteus medius represented by 2.

The gluteus medius originates from the outer surface of the ileum between the anterior and posterior gluteal lines. Insertion of the muscle is at the lateral surface of the greater trochanter. It is supplied by the superior gluteal nerve.

Gluteus medius and minimus are powerful abductors of the hip joint. Mechanism of actions of gluteus medius and minimus:

  • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in a slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.
  • The actions of these muscles are affected when there is an injury to the superior gluteal nerve, neck of the femur, or loss of normal angulation of the shaft of the femur. This occurs in conditions like paralysis of the glutei, developmental dysplasia of the hip, etc.
  • When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported (normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb. This leads to a positive Trendelenburg's sign with a characteristic lurching gait - the patient lurches towards the affected side with contralateral pelvis drop. 

Other options

1 - Gluteus maximus - involved in the extension of flexed thigh, abduction (only upper fibres), and lateral rotation at the hip joint. Insertion is at the iliotibial tract. 

3 - Piriformis - involved in lateral rotation and assists abduction at the hip joint. It is inserted into the medial side of greater trochanter of the femur. Entrapment of the sciatic nerve in the piriformis can lead to piriformis syndrome.

4 - Sciatic nerve - The nerve passes over the obturator internus, gemellus superior, gemellus inferior and quadratus femoris. It supplies knee flexors and muscles below the knee. Paralysis of this nerve results in flail foot and severe difficulty in walking. 

Related Pearl: Muscles causing the movements at Hip joint

Psoas major

Iliacus

Rectus femoris

Gluteus maximus

Biceps femoris

Semitendinosus

Gluteus medius

Gluteus minimus

Assisted by tensor fascia lata, piriformis and sartorius.

Adductor brevis

Gracilis.

Gluteus minimus

questions.text: A patient presented with paradoxical respiration. Which of the following nerves (as marked in the image below) is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Paradoxical respiration occurs due to the damage of the phrenic nerve, which is marked as D, in the given image.

The structures marked in the image are:

A. Right vagus nerve

B. Left vagus nerve

C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve

D. Right phrenic nerve

Paradoxical respiration refers to the abnormal movement of the chest wall or abdominal wall, where they move in during inspiration instead of moving out.

It may be caused due to several conditions, which include:

  • Flail chest: caused due to blunt trauma causing fracture of 2 adjacent ribs or 3 or more ribs fractured in two or more places
  • Diaphragmatic paralysis: caused due to the damage to the phrenic nerve on one or both sides

questions.text: Marked structure is derived from the______
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the membranous part of the interventricular septum that is derived from endocardial cushions.

Endocardial cushions are soft tissue masses that protrude in the atrioventricular and conotruncal regions. 

  • Atrioventricular cushions are derived from overlying endocardial cells.
  • The conotruncal cushions are derived from the neural crest cells. 

Endocardial cushions contribute to the formation of:

  • Atrial septa
  • Ventricular septa (membranous portion)
  • Atrioventricular canals
  • Atrioventricular valves
  • Aortic and pulmonary channels

Defects in endocardial cushion formation can result in cardiac malformations, including ASDs, VSDs and defects involving the great vessels (transposition of the great vessels, common truncus arteriosus, and tetralogy of Fallot).

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not supplied by the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is ansa cervicalis and thyrohyoid is not supplied by it. 

Ansa cervicalis: 

  • It is a loop of nerves which are a part of cervical plexus.
  • It is made up of two roots.
    • The upper root has contributions from the first cervical spinal nerve
    • The lower root has contributions from the second and third cervical spinal nerves.
  • It innervates sternohyoid, sternothyroid and omohyoid muscles.

Thyrohyoid and geniohyoid are not supplied by ansa cervicalis. They are supplied by the first cervical spinal nerve, via the hypoglossal nerve.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the red arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the musculocutaneous nerve. 

The structure can be identified as the musculocutaneous nerve as it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle in its course and also supplies the biceps brachii. The root value of the musculocutaneous nerve is C5, C6, C7.

The musculocutaneous nerve supplies all the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm, which include coracobrachialis, brachialis, and biceps brachii muscles.

questions.text: All of the following supply the marked structure except :
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the right ventricle. It is not supplied by the diagonal artery.

The diagonal artery is a branch of the anterior interventricular artery supplying the left ventricle. This is present in about 30-50% of the population.

The right ventricle is mostly supplied by the right coronary artery and its branches such as the marginal artery. (Options A and C)

The anterior interventricular artery gives off 1-2 anterior right ventricular branches. (Option B)

questions.text: A specimen of the posterior surface of the larynx is kept in an anatomy practical exam and a structure is marked with red. What would be the action of the structure?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the posterior view of the larynx and the marked muscle is the posterior cricoarytenoid. Its action is to abduct the vocal cords and open the glottis. The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is identified by its origin from the posterior surface of the cricoid. 

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle arises from the posterior surface of the cricoid lamina and is attached to the upper and posterior surfaces of the muscular processes of the ipsilateral arytenoids. It is innervated by a branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. They are active in the production of unvoiced sounds.

The image below shows the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)
Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis

Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

Related Pearl: Cartilages of Larynx

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle at the hip, which is attached to the marked area in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the posterior surface of the femur, and the structure marked is gluteal tuberosity, to which the gluteus maximus muscle is attached. The action of gluteus Maximus is the extension and lateral rotation of the hip joint.

The gluteus maximus muscle, which is the chief extensor of the thigh at the hip joint, has superficial and deep fibres. The deep fibres insert into the gluteal tuberosity, and the superficial fibres insert into the iliotibial tract. 

The Gluteus maximus muscle is supplied by the inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2). It is an antigravity muscle and it plays a key role in standing up from a sitting position and maintaining an erect posture. Its other actions include lateral rotation and abduction of the thigh and knee stabilization in conjunction with the tensor fasciae latae muscle. 

The image below shows attachments of various muscles over the posterior surface of the right femur.

Related Pearl: Muscles causing the movements at Hip joint

Movements Principal muscles involved in the movements
Flexion

Psoas major

Iliacus

Rectus femoris
Extension

Related Pearl: Gluteal Muscles

 
Gluteus Medius
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines.
Insertion -Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.
Gluteus Minimus
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and inferior gluteal lines
Insertion -Ridge on the anterior surface of greater trochanter
Gluteus Maximus

Origin - Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium posterior to posterior gluteal line, posterior superior iliac crest, posterior inferior aspect of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion - Primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band; also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface

questions.text: All of the following form the marked structure except:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the dorsal digital expansion of the middle finger. Palmar interossei do not attach to the middle finger and therefore it does not contribute to the dorsal digital expansion of the middle finger. 

Palmar interossei are unipennate muscles originating from their own metacarpal bone. Their function is adduction. The middle finger does not need adduction and hence does not have palmar interossei.

Dorsal interossei are bipennate muscles originating from the adjacent metacarpal bone. They attach to the middle three fingers on both sides and do not attach on the thumb and little finger. Their function is abduction. The thumb and little finger have other muscles for abduction.

The lateral 2 lumbricals are unipennate and medial 2 lumbricals are bipennate. Their function is flexion at metacarpophalangeal joints.

questions.text: Identify the bony prominence marked in the image below
questions.solution:
The bone depicted in the above image is the Femur and the bony prominence marked "A" is the lesser trochanter.

The image below shows attachments of various muscles over the posterior surface of the right femur.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is related to the area marked as A in the given image below?
questions.solution:
The cadaveric image shown is of the left lung. The arch of aorta is related to the area marked as A in the given image. 

The left lung is divided into superior and inferior lobes by the oblique fissure. The pulmonary root connects the medial surface of the lung to the heart and trachea. It is formed by structures that enter or leave the hilum. The left root is present inferior to the arch of the aorta.

The vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum from above to below is:

  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal (hyparterial) bronchus, and
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

The arrangement of the lung hilar structures from the anterior to posterior in the order is:

  • Pulmonary vein
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Primary bronchus
  • Bronchial artery

The cadaveric image given below shows the structures related to the hilum of the left lung.

The cadaveric image given below shows the structures related to the hilum of the right lung.

questions.text: True regarding the lesion of the structure marked by the red arrow  is:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the radial nerve demonstrated in the cubital fossa. A lesion of the radial nerve leads to a wrist drop.

Claw hand deformity is seen in a lesion of the ulnar nerve. (Option B)

Ape thumb deformity is seen in a lesion of the median nerve. (Option A)

Contrast the cadaveric image showing the anterior view with the schematic image below showing a posterior view of Radial Nerve course
